description: Crosstalk refers to unwanted interactions between qubits that cause operations on one qubit to affect neighboring qubits. This is a major error source in multi-qubit systems and becomes increasingly problematic as qubit counts grow.

In superconducting qubits, always-on ZZ coupling is a dominant form of crosstalk: even when no gate is applied, neighboring qubits accumulate a conditional phase. In trapped ions, crosstalk arises from imperfect addressing of individual ions.
Crosstalk errors are typically coherent and correlated across qubits, making them difficult to model and mitigate with techniques designed for independent, stochastic errors.

quantum_channel.kraus_form: U_{\text{crosstalk}} = \exp(-i \zeta t \, Z_i \otimes Z_j) \quad \text{for ZZ coupling}
quantum_channel.effect: States with different parity acquire a relative phase: |01⟩ and |10⟩ accumulate phase 2ζt relative to |00⟩ and |11⟩

properties.Parameters: ζ = coupling strength (Hz); depends on qubit pair

physical_examples: ZZ coupling in fixed-frequency transmon qubits
Addressing errors in trapped ion chains
Shared microwave drive lines affecting multiple qubits
qem_considerations: Crosstalk-adaptive scheduling (XtalkSched) avoids simultaneous operations on high-crosstalk pairs
Dynamical decoupling can suppress idle ZZ crosstalk
Pauli twirling converts coherent crosstalk to stochastic errors
Noise-aware compilation routes circuits to minimize crosstalk exposure
Sparse Pauli-Lindblad models (PEA, NOX) can capture and mitigate correlated errors
